Posts.Title: Oncotype dx

Posts.Content: Hi Moonstar Sorry to jump in on your posts ladies.  I had a 27mm, grade 3, ER+ HER2- tumour removed in November. Clear margins and no node involvement.  The standard NHS test wasn’t decisive so I had the Oncotype DX test. My score came back as 21 which is in the dreaded grey area. My Onco couldn’t say if I would benefit from chemo or not which gave me a dilemma that I didn’t want.  The confusing part re the scoring is that the low cut off is 18, mid is 19 to 30 and above 30 is high. She said that in America they give chemo as low as 11 but felt it’s over used as a treatment there.  I asked about the newer EndoPredict test as this only gives a low or high score. It’s not available yet on the NHS but you can pay for it so I’ve decided to do so. I will have the results within the next few days.  I just don’t want to have chemo unnecessarily or at all if I’m honest but being in the middle with 21 means it’s my decision alone and I couldn’t make that choice. I am a ‘what if’ person so I need an answer that makes that decision for me one way or the other.  Apologies if the post is a bit long xxxx

Posts.Content: Careermindedoptimist  I had IDC a grade 3, 2.7m ER+ HER-, clear nodes and clear margins as had WLE. My oncotype score was 21 so low intermediate. I was told prior that the cut off for no chemo at my trust was 18 but no discussion of chemo if 19, 20 21 but prepared to if it was 25 or above. My onco did discuss chemo with me even at 21 but would not make a decision for me either way, I told her I just couldn’t make that decision myself. I didn’t want chemo however I was worried that I may be making the wrong decision just based on fear of what chemo would do to me. I opted to pay privately via my onco for the Endopredict test which only gives a high or low result for recurrence. Surprisingly to me and to her I came back as a high risk so chemo it was. I have just had my 3rd EC and nobody would tell you it’s easy but it is very doable. I feel now that I’m throwing everything possible at this and don’t regret my decision. I have 15 rounds of radiotherapy after my chemo has finished and will be on Letrozole.  I really hope your score is low because that intermediate area is too big in my opinion (19 to 30) and to be left to actually make that decision is a really tough call.  please me back and let us know how you get on xxxxxx

My second chemo and that was it, it started just dropping out and the last lot was in the shower. So in total I would say all of mine was gone within 28 days of starting chemo.  I ordered some silk pillowcases from amazon with a cotton back to stop them slipping and they really help the scalp at night, cotton can be a bit rough. They are definitely worth buying, I think I got 2 for about £20 so swap and wash.  Also my wig lady recommended that I didn’t shave my head as stubble is more troublesome when it’s done too early. I’m glad I didn’t shave as I never went through the stubble phase, I just ended up with a smooth scalp.  Hope this helps Jackie xxxxxxx
Posts.Title: *** April 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Hi Zebrano  Sorry to hear you’ve been so poorly, I haven’t put make up on for a while either. I’ve had my last chemo and start RT soon so  have started thinking about a bit of normality and about making myself look and feel better. Yes losing lashes and brows does make a difference to how we look. For me it’s definitely the lashes, I’m sure there are tips out there on how to apply make up to make it appear they are there. I was hoping the LGFB course would have good advice on it, I’m going on Monday afternoon so will share anything that may be useful for anyone that hasnt been on it.  Hope you’re all having the best weekend possible xx
